src package¶

Submodules¶

src.JS_scripts module¶

Author: Alpha Team Group Project Date: March 2023 Purpose: JS_scripts module contains script to insert into the plotly graph for dynamic functionality

src.NetworkGraphs module¶

Author: Alpha Team Group Project Date: March 2023 Purpose: NetworkGraphs.py contains the NetworkGraphs custom class to generalise complex network analysis

class src.NetworkGraphs.NetworkGraphs(filename, type, session_folder=None, temporal=False, spatial=False, weighted=False, attack_vector=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

Class containing the NetworkX graphs wrapping functionalities to generalise the use of the MultiDiGraph, MultiGraph, DiGraph and Graph. This class store attributes of the graphs to allow effective use of the graphs.

src.metrics.get_metrics(networkGraphs, method, directed=False, multi=False)[source]¶
Function:

Get the metrics for the given graph Method: - ‘kcore’ - ‘degree’ - ‘triangles’ - ‘pagerank’ - ‘betweenness_centrality’ - ‘closeness_centrality’ - ‘eigenvector_centrality’ - ‘load_centrality’ - ‘degree_centrality’

Parameters:

  • networkGraphs (NetworkGraphs) – Network graphs

  • method (str) – Method to compute the metrics

  • directed (bool) – Compute the metrics for the directed graph

  • multi (bool) – Compute the metrics for the multi graph

Returns:

Pandas dataframe with the metrics and values

pd.DataFrame

src.preprocessing.convert_to_DiGraph(multi_graph)[source]¶
Function:

Create a DiGraph from a MultiDiGraph with the same nodes and edges containing the sum of the weights,

and conserving the first edge’s attributes

NetworkX DiGraph

src.preprocessing.preprocess_custom(filename_: str)[source]¶
Function:

Preprocess the custom dataset and return a NetworkX DiGraph and MultiDiGraph

Dataset must have the following columns:

  • from: Source node

  • to: Target node

Dataset could have the following columns:

  • weight: Edge weight

  • start: Start time of the edge

  • end: End time of the edge

  • color: Color of the edge

  • lat1: Latitude of the source node

  • lon1: Longitude of the source node

  • lat2: Latitude of the target node

  • lon2: Longitude of the target node

Parameters:

filename (str) – Path to the custom dataset

Returns:

List of NetworkX DiGraph and MultiDiGraph

Return type:

list

src.preprocessing.preprocess_gtfs(zip_file)[source]¶
Function:

Preprocess the gtfs dataset and return a NetworkX DiGraph and MultiDiGraph

Parameters:

zip_file (str) – Path to the gtfs dataset

Returns:

List of NetworkX DiGraph and MultiDiGraph

Return type:

list

src.resilience.resilience(networkGraph, attack, **kwargs)[source]¶
Function:

Compute the resilience of the networkGraph

Attack can be:

  • “random”

  • “malicious”

  • “cluster”

  • “random”

Args of the attacks:
  • “random”:

    • “number_of_nodes”: Number of nodes to be removed

    • “number_of_edges”: Number of edges to be removed

  • “malicious”:
    • “metric”: Metric to be used to select the nodes to be removed

      • ‘kcore’

      • ‘degree’

      • ‘triangles’

      • ‘pagerank’

      • ‘betweenness_centrality’

      • ‘closeness_centrality’

      • ‘eigenvector_centrality’

      • ‘load_centrality’

      • ‘degree_centrality’

    • ‘directed’: True or False

    • ‘multi’: True or False

    • “number_of_nodes”: Number of nodes to be removed

    • “threshold”: Threshold to be used to select the nodes to be removed

    • “operator” can be:

      • “>”

      • “<”

      • “>=”

      • “<=”

  • “cluster”:

    • “cluster_algorithm”: Algorithm to be used to compute the clusters

    • “total_clusters”: Total number of clusters to be generated

    • “number_of_clusters”: Number of clusters to be removed

  • “custom”:

    • “list_of_nodes”: List of nodes to be removed

Parameters:

  • networkGraph (NetworkGraph) – NetworkGraph

  • attack (str) – Attack to be performed

  • kwargs (dict) – Arguments of the attack to be performed

Returns:

NetworkGraph with the nodes removed, and a dataframe with the changed nodes/edges

Return type:

NetworkGraph, pd.DataFrame

Example: >>> # Random attack >>> graph, df = resilience(networkGraph, attack=’random’, number_of_nodes=10) >>> graph, df = resilience(networkGraph, attack=’random’, number_of_edges=10) >>> # Malicious attack >>> graph, df = resilience(networkGraph, attack=’malicious’, metric=’degree’, number_of_nodes=10) >>> graph, df = resilience(networkGraph, attack=’malicious’, metric=’degree’, threshold=10, operator=’>’) >>> # Cluster attack >>> graph, df = resilience(networkGraph, attack=’cluster’, cluster_algorithm=’spectral’, total_clusters=15, number_of_clusters=2) >>> # Custom attack >>> graph, df = resilience(networkGraph, attack=’custom’, list_of_nodes=[1, 2, 3])

src.resilience.resilience_cluster(networkGraph, cluster_algorithm=None, total_clusters=0, number_of_clusters=0)[source]¶
Function:

Generate the cluster attack to the networkGraph

Parameters:

  • networkGraph (NetworkGraph) – NetworkGraph

  • cluster_algorithm (str) – Algorithm to be used to compute the clusters

  • total_clusters (int) – Total number of clusters to be generated

  • number_of_clusters (int) – Number of clusters to be removed

Returns:

NetworkGraph with the nodes removed

Return type:

NetworkGraph

  • list_of_nodes (list) – List of nodes to be removed

Returns:

NetworkGraph with the nodes removed

Return type:

NetworkGraph

src.resilience.resilience_malicious(networkGraph, metric=None, number_of_nodes=None, threshold=None, operator='>', multi=False, directed=False)[source]¶
Function:

Generate the malicious attack to the networkGraph

Metrics:

  • ‘kcore’

  • ‘degree’

  • ‘triangles’

  • ‘pagerank’

  • ‘betweenness_centrality’

  • ‘closeness_centrality’

  • ‘eigenvector_centrality’

  • ‘load_centrality’

  • ‘degree_centrality’

operators:

  • “>” (default)

  • “<”

  • “>=”

  • “<=”

Parameters:

  • networkGraph (NetworkGraph) – NetworkGraph

  • metric (str) – Metric to be used to select the nodes to be removed

  • number_of_nodes (int) – Number of nodes to be removed

  • threshold (float) – Threshold to be used to select the nodes to be removed

  • operator (str) – Operator to be used to select the nodes to be removed

  • multi (bool) – True if the graph is multi

  • directed (bool) – True if the graph is directed

Returns:

NetworkGraph with the nodes removed

Return type:

NetworkGraph

src.visualisation module¶

Author: Alpha Team Group Project Date: May 2023 Purpose: Main visualisation file wrapping sub-visualisation functionalities

this file is used to generate the API calls by the user

src.visualisation.plot_DL_embedding(networkGraphs, features=['proximity'], dimension=128, model='SAGE', layout='TSNE', fullPath=False)[source]¶
Function:

Plot the DL embedding for the given network

features:

Format: [‘feature1’, ‘feature2’, …] If choose proximity just put [‘proximity’] without any other features - ‘proximity’ - ‘kcore’ - ‘triangles’ - ‘degree’ - ‘pagerank’ - ‘degree_centrality’ - ‘closeness_centrality’ - ‘betweenness_centrality’ - ‘eigenvector_centrality’ - ‘load_centrality’

layout:

  • ‘TSNE’

  • ‘UMAP’

  • ‘PCA’

Parameters:

  • networkGraphs (NetworkGraphs) – NetworkGraphs object

  • features (list) – Feature list

  • dimension (int) – Dimension of the embedding

  • model (str) – GNN model

  • layout (str) – Visualisation method

  • fullPath (bool) – Boolean to indicate if the full path is required

Returns:

DataFrame, filename

Return type:

pd.DataFrame, str

src.visualisation.plot_DL_embedding_cluster(networkGraphs, method, noOfCluster=8, features=['proximity'], dimension=128, model='SAGE', layout='TSNE', fullPath=False)[source]¶
Function:

Plot the DL embeddings with clusters on top for the given network

method:

  • ‘kmeans’

  • ‘spectral’

  • ‘agglomerative’

  • ‘dbscan’

features:

Format: [‘feature1’, ‘feature2’, …] If choose proximity just put [‘proximity’] without any other features - ‘proximity’ - ‘kcore’ - ‘triangles’ - ‘degree’ - ‘pagerank’ - ‘degree_centrality’ - ‘closeness_centrality’ - ‘betweenness_centrality’ - ‘eigenvector_centrality’ - ‘load_centrality’

layout:

  • ‘TSNE’

  • ‘UMAP’

  • ‘PCA’

  • ‘sfdp’

  • ‘twopi’

  • ‘map’

Parameters:

  • networkGraphs (NetworkGraphs) – NetworkGraphs object

  • method (str) – Clustering method

  • noOfCluster (int) – Number of clusters

  • features (list) – Feature list

  • dimension (int) – Dimension of the embedding

  • model (str) – GNN model

  • layout (str) – Visualisation method

  • fullPath (bool) – Boolean to indicate if the full path is required

Returns:

DataFrame, filename

Return type:

pd.DataFrame, str

src.visualisation.plot_histogram(networkGraphs, metrics, directed=True, multi=True, fullPath=False)[source]¶
Function:

Plot the histogram distribution for a given metric

Metrics:

  • ‘kcore’

  • ‘degree’

  • ‘triangles’

  • ‘pagerank’

  • ‘betweenness_centrality’

  • ‘closeness_centrality’

  • ‘eigenvector_centrality’

  • ‘load_centrality’

  • ‘degree_centrality’

  • ‘centralities’ - All centralities

  • ‘nodes’ - All node metrics

  • ‘clustering_coefficient’ - Stochastic clustering coefficient

  • ‘shortest_path’ - Stochastic shortest path

Parameters:

  • networkGraphs (NetworkGraphs) – Network graphs

  • metrics (str) – Metrics to be plotted

  • directed (bool) – Boolean to indicate if the graph is directed or not

  • multi (bool) – for multi graphs

  • fullPath (bool) – Boolean to indicate if the full path is required

Returns:

df and filename

Return type:

pd.DataFrame, str
